<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A novel organic–inorganic hybrid compound: K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)[Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(BpyEt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>W<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">62</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (bpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-bipyridine; BpyEt<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-ethylbipyridine cation) was hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by routine techniques and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The compound is a 3D architecture constructed by saturated Dawson polyoxoanions and transition-metal coordination complexes (containing <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-ethylated bpy) [Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(BpyEt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], in which the [P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>W<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">62</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup> (P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>W<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>) clusters are modified by five Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N coordination polymeric chains. The striking feature of the structures is that there are three kinds of coordination geometries for copper<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> ions, which are responsible for the formation of polymeric structures. It is also interesting that <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-ethylated bpy was firstly in the high dimensional POM framework.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel organic-inorganic hybrid compound: K2(H3O)[CuI 7(Bpy)6(BpyEt)2][P2W18O62]2⋅6H2O 1 (bpy=4,4'-bipyridine; BpyEt+ = N-ethylbipyridine cation) was hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by routine techniques and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The compound is a 3D architecture constructed by saturated Dawson polyoxoanions and transition-metal coordination complexes (containing N-ethylated bpy) [CuI 7(Bpy)6(BpyEt)2], in which the [P2W18O62]6- (P2W18) clusters are modified by five CuI N coordination polymeric chains. The striking feature of the structures is that there are three kinds of coordination geometries for copperI ions, which are responsible for the formation of polymeric structures. It is also interesting that N-ethylated bpy was firstly in the high dimensional POM framework.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Organic–inorganic hybrid compounds have been attracting considerable interest as a promising new class of materials that often have unexpected architectures, special characteristics, or even new synergetic functional properties in the complementary design of solid-state structures with different composites . The evolution of organic–inorganic hybrid compounds is dependent upon the synthesis of new solids possessing unique structures and properties, although the synthetic design of such materials remains a challenge in solid-state chemistry. One approach for the design of organic–inorganic hybrid compounds is to introduce some interesting transition-metal (TM) coordination complexes, which serve as organic–inorganic bridging ligands, into the covalent backbone of inorganic oxides .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Organic-inorganic hybrid compounds have been attracting considerable interest as a promising new class of materials that often have unexpected architectures, special characteristics, or even new synergetic functional properties in the complementary design of solid-state structures with different composites . The evolution of organic-inorganic hybrid compounds is dependent upon the synthesis of new solids possessing unique structures and properties, although the synthetic design of such materials remains a challenge in solid-state chemistry. One approach for the design of organic-inorganic hybrid compounds is to introduce some interesting transition-metal (TM) coordination complexes, which serve as organic-inorganic bridging ligands, into the covalent backbone of inorganic oxides .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Meanwhile, polyoxometalates (POMs), as an important family of metal oxide, bearing unique properties and exhibiting a diverse compositional range, represent an outstanding class of inorganic building blocks for the construction of such kinds of materials, which give rise to a variety of applications in fields such as catalysis, medicine, and magnetism . Consequently, the functionality of organic–inorganic hybrid materials based on POMs can be multiplied by the incorporation of inorganic and organic counterparts into one structural unit . To date, several of these hybrid compounds based on Keggin polyoxoanions have been reported ; in contrast, examples of constructing Dawson polyoxoanions as building blocks are much less . In reported compounds, the saturated Dawson polyoxoanions are connected by finite molecular units and most of them are 1D chain-like structures. Therefore, the exploration of feasible synthetic routes to construct extended framework based on saturated Dawson polyoxoanions and transition-metal coordination complexes is an appealing issue.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Meanwhile, polyoxometalates (POMs), as an important family of metal oxide, bearing unique properties and exhibiting a diverse compositional range, represent an outstanding class of inorganic building blocks for the construction of such kinds of materials, which give rise to a variety of applications in fields such as catalysis, medicine, and magnetism . Consequently, the functionality of organic-inorganic hybrid materials based on POMs can be multiplied by the incorporation of inorganic and organic counterparts into one structural unit . To date, several of these hybrid compounds based on Keggin polyoxoanions have been reported ; in contrast, examples of constructing Dawson polyoxoanions as building blocks are much less . In reported compounds, the saturated Dawson polyoxoanions are connected by finite molecular units and most of them are 1D chain-like structures. Therefore, the exploration of feasible synthetic routes to construct extended framework based on saturated Dawson polyoxoanions and transition-metal coordination complexes is an appealing issue.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">We have launched a program aimed at linking saturated Dawson polyoxoanions building blocks by organic ligand coordinated transition-metal complexes to generate unusual architectures. By hydrothermal condition, we report here the synthesis, structural characterization of a hybrid compound with 3D architecture: K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)[Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(BpyEt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>W<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">62</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (bpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-bipyridine; BpyEt<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>

<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-ethylbipyridine cation). This compound exhibits the example of saturated Dawson polyoxoanions modifying by transition-metal coordination polymeric chains with 3D. It is also interesting that <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-ethylated bpy was firstly in the high dimensional POM framework.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We have launched a program aimed at linking saturated Dawson polyoxoanions building blocks by organic ligand coordinated transition-metal complexes to generate unusual architectures. By hydrothermal condition, we report here the synthesis, structural characterization of a hybrid compound with 3D architecture: K2(H3O)[CuI 7(Bpy)6(BpyEt)2][P2W18O62]2⋅6H2O 1 (bpy=4,4'-bipyridine; BpyEt+ = N-ethylbipyridine cation). This compound exhibits the example of saturated Dawson polyoxoanions modifying by transition-metal coordination polymeric chains with 3D. It is also interesting that N-ethylated bpy was firstly in the high dimensional POM framework.

All other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a PLASMA-SPEC(I) ICP atomic-emission spectrometer (P, W, and Cu) and a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer (C, H, and N). IR spectra were recorded in the range of 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. X-ray powder diffraction measurements were performed on a Rigaku D/MAX-3 instrument with Cu-Kα radiation in the angular range 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3–60° at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials

The K6P2W18O62⋅14H2O was prepared according to the literature  method and confirmed by IR spectroscopy. All other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a PLASMA-SPEC(I) ICP atomic-emission spectrometer (P, W, and Cu) and a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer (C, H, and N). IR spectra were recorded in the range of 400-4000cm-1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. X-ray powder diffraction measurements were performed on a Rigaku D/MAX-3 instrument with Cu-Kα radiation in the angular range 2θ =3-60° at 293K.

The mixture was then sealed in a 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon reactor and kept under autogenous pressure at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 5 days, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. elements.clean_text:
Preparation of compound 1 

A mixture of K6P2W18O62⋅14H2O (0.5g, 0.1mmol), Cu(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.088g, 0.3mmol), oxalic acid dihydrate (0.02g, 0.2mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (0.062g, 0.4mmol) in a mixture of ethanol (2mL) and H2O (8mL) was stirred for 30min (pH about 2.0). The mixture was then sealed in a 23mL Teflon reactor and kept under autogenous pressure at 160°C for 5 days, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10°Ch-1. Red crystals were obtained in 54% yield (based on W). Anal. Calcd (%) for C84H89Cu7K2N16O131P4W36 (10683.78): C, 9.44; H, 0.84; Cu, 4.16; K, 0.73; N, 2.09; P, 1.15; W, 61.95. Found (%): C, 9.86; H, 0.83; Cu, 4.00; K, 0.68; N, 2.00; P, 1.06; W, 61.75.

<ce:section-title>X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Crystal data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was collected at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K on Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer (graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation: <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The linear absorption coefficients, scattering factors for the atoms, and the anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. Absorption correction was applied. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> using the SHELXTL crystallographic software package . Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all weight atoms, some oxygen of polyoxoanions and carbon atoms of bpy ligands, except for the oxygen atoms of water molecules. No attempt was made to locate the hydrogen atoms of water molecules. Hydrogen atoms on the bpy ligands and <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-ethylated bpy ligands were placed on calculated positions and included in the refinement riding on their respective parent atoms. One lattice water molecules set half-occupied in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Details of the crystal data and final structure refinements of the compound are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are provided in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Crystal data for 1 was collected at 293K on Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer (graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation: λ =0.71073Å). The linear absorption coefficients, scattering factors for the atoms, and the anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. Absorption correction was applied. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 using the SHELXTL crystallographic software package . Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all weight atoms, some oxygen of polyoxoanions and carbon atoms of bpy ligands, except for the oxygen atoms of water molecules. No attempt was made to locate the hydrogen atoms of water molecules. Hydrogen atoms on the bpy ligands and N-ethylated bpy ligands were placed on calculated positions and included in the refinement riding on their respective parent atoms. One lattice water molecules set half-occupied in 1. Details of the crystal data and final structure refinements of the compound are summarized in  . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are provided in .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis and structure</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">When a mixture of K<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>W<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">62</ce:inf>·14H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, oxalic acid dihydrate, and 4,4′-bipyridine in a mixture of ethanol and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O reacts under hydrothermal condition, the title compound was obtained. Hydrothermal synthesis has recently been proved to be a particularly useful technique for the preparation of organic–inorganic hybrid materials. However, hydrothermal synthesis is still a relatively complex process because many factors can influence the outcome of reaction , so that it is known to generate, sometimes, surprisingly new and unexpected phases. Here, when we attempted the utilization of oxalic acid to the design synthesis of new inorganic–organic hybrid compounds, an unexpected <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-ethylbipyridine cation was produced in the transition-metal coordination complexes together with the saturated Dawson polyoxoanions built up of a 3D structure. The addition of oxalic acid is crucial for the successful synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, reaction mixtures without it fail to produce the same crystalline phase. Herein, we presumed that the formation process and reaction mechanism of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>. Based on the previous results , the transfer of ethyl group from the source, which is ethanol, to bipyridine nitrogen, takes place only in the presence of oxalic acid and group 6 metal oxoanions. In addition, the nature of the transition-metal is significant for the formation of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. In the synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> the oxidation state of copper was changed from a reactant copper<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion to a resultant copper<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> ion . Because of the coordination preferences of the transtion metal, binding mode of the ligand adapt various coordination geometries in different oxidation states, we replaced CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O with CoCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and or NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in the synthesis of the compound, 3D host metal-organic frameworks based on mixed oxalic acid and bpy ligands were obtained. The experimental and simulated X-ray powder diffraction patterns (XRPD) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is shown in . The diffraction peaks on the patterns match well in position, indicating this phase purity.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and structure

When a mixture of K6P2W18O62⋅14H2O, Cu(NO3)2⋅6H2O, oxalic acid dihydrate, and 4,4'-bipyridine in a mixture of ethanol and H2O reacts under hydrothermal condition, the title compound was obtained. Hydrothermal synthesis has recently been proved to be a particularly useful technique for the preparation of organic-inorganic hybrid materials. However, hydrothermal synthesis is still a relatively complex process because many factors can influence the outcome of reaction , so that it is known to generate, sometimes, surprisingly new and unexpected phases. Here, when we attempted the utilization of oxalic acid to the design synthesis of new inorganic-organic hybrid compounds, an unexpected N-ethylbipyridine cation was produced in the transition-metal coordination complexes together with the saturated Dawson polyoxoanions built up of a 3D structure. The addition of oxalic acid is crucial for the successful synthesis of 1, reaction mixtures without it fail to produce the same crystalline phase. Herein, we presumed that the formation process and reaction mechanism of compound 1 in  . Based on the previous results , the transfer of ethyl group from the source, which is ethanol, to bipyridine nitrogen, takes place only in the presence of oxalic acid and group 6 metal oxoanions. In addition, the nature of the transition-metal is significant for the formation of compound 1. In the synthesis of 1 the oxidation state of copper was changed from a reactant copperII ion to a resultant copperI ion . Because of the coordination preferences of the transtion metal, binding mode of the ligand adapt various coordination geometries in different oxidation states, we replaced CuCl2⋅2H2O with CoCl2⋅6H2O and or NiCl2⋅6H2O in the synthesis of the compound, 3D host metal-organic frameworks based on mixed oxalic acid and bpy ligands were obtained. The experimental and simulated X-ray powder diffraction patterns (XRPD) of 1 is shown in . The diffraction peaks on the patterns match well in position, indicating this phase purity.

</mml:math> is a classical Dawson-type structure, which may be described as two [α-PW<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">34</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> units, generated from the well-known [α-PW<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> by removal of a set of three corner-sharing WO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedra and fused into a cluster of virtual <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3h</ce:inf> symmetry. In the polyoxoanion, the two central P atoms are tetrahedronly coordinated by four bridging oxygen atoms, forming two {PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} clusters. The corresponding P<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond distances vary from 1.516(13) to 1.568(14). The polyoxoanion contains only two structurally distinct types of W atoms: six polar W atoms on vertical mirror planes grouped in two sets of three and twelve equatorial W atoms that do not lie on mirror planes grouped in two sets of six. According to the different manner of oxygen coordination, four kinds of O atoms exist in the polyoxoanion: 18 terminal O atoms only bonded to one W atom, 36 bridging O atoms shared by two W atoms, 6 bridging O atoms combined with one central P atom and two W atoms, and 2 bridging O atoms coordinated to one central P atom and three W atoms. The corresponding W<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond distances vary from 1.660(14) to 1.733(15), 1.860(13) to 1.978(14), 2.290(11) to 2.466(12), and 2.359(14) to 2.406(13)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. All bond lengths are within the normal ranges and consist with those described in the literatures. Further studies reveal that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 3D architecture, in which each P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>W<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf> cluster acts as tetra-dentate ligand covalently bonding to five copper centers (shown in b). There are four crystallographically independent Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> atoms, which have three different coordination geometries. Cu1 displays a linear {CuN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} coordination geometry, and Cu2 and Cu3 are four-coordinated, defined by two nitrogen atoms from 4,4′-bipyridine and two terminal oxygen from the P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>W<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf> cluster, while Cu4 residing in a T-shaped geometry, is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from 4,4′-bipyridine and a terminal oxygen from the P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>W<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf> cluster. The Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond lengths are in the range of 2.268(17)–2.746(17)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond lengths are in the range of 1.858(19)–1.931(19)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>). The 4,4′-bipyridine groups serve as bidentate ligands and bridge adjacent copper centers. Because of the <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-ethylbipyridine cation present, precluding coordination to the transition-metal and resulting in the seven copper atoms form 1D [Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(BpyEt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] chains. The connection of alternating the equatorial terminal O atoms of P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>W<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf> clusters and the Cu2 and Cu3 atoms of [Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(BpyEt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] chains forms a unique 2D layer (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>), and two adjacent 2D layers are linked by Cu4 atoms of [Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(BpyEt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] chains via Cu<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O (the polar terminal O atoms) bonds, resulting in a 3D network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>a). For perspicuous representation, the P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>W<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf> clusters are represented by quadrangle and bpy ligands are represented by sticks (b). The 3D network can be simplified as a ladder like motif (b). The bond-valence calculations  indicate that all the O atoms in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are in the -2 oxidation state, and that all W atoms are in the +6 oxidation state and all Cu atoms are in the +1 oxidation state, which has further been confirmed by the absence of signal in the EPR spectrum of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of a     P   2     W   18     O   62   6 -     polyoxoanion, a K+ ion, a [CuI 3.5(Bpy)3(BpyEt)]9/2+ moieties and 3.5 water molecules ( a). The polyoxoanion     P   2     W   18     O   62   6 -     is a classical Dawson-type structure, which may be described as two [α-PW9O34]3- units, generated from the well-known [α-PW12O40]3- by removal of a set of three corner-sharing WO6 octahedra and fused into a cluster of virtual D 3h symmetry. In the polyoxoanion, the two central P atoms are tetrahedronly coordinated by four bridging oxygen atoms, forming two {PO4} clusters. The corresponding PO bond distances vary from 1.516(13) to 1.568(14). The polyoxoanion contains only two structurally distinct types of W atoms: six polar W atoms on vertical mirror planes grouped in two sets of three and twelve equatorial W atoms that do not lie on mirror planes grouped in two sets of six. According to the different manner of oxygen coordination, four kinds of O atoms exist in the polyoxoanion: 18 terminal O atoms only bonded to one W atom, 36 bridging O atoms shared by two W atoms, 6 bridging O atoms combined with one central P atom and two W atoms, and 2 bridging O atoms coordinated to one central P atom and three W atoms. The corresponding WO bond distances vary from 1.660(14) to 1.733(15), 1.860(13) to 1.978(14), 2.290(11) to 2.466(12), and 2.359(14) to 2.406(13)Å, respectively. All bond lengths are within the normal ranges and consist with those described in the literatures. Further studies reveal that 1 is a 3D architecture, in which each P2W18 cluster acts as tetra-dentate ligand covalently bonding to five copper centers (shown in b). There are four crystallographically independent CuI atoms, which have three different coordination geometries. Cu1 displays a linear {CuN2} coordination geometry, and Cu2 and Cu3 are four-coordinated, defined by two nitrogen atoms from 4,4'-bipyridine and two terminal oxygen from the P2W18 cluster, while Cu4 residing in a T-shaped geometry, is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from 4,4'-bipyridine and a terminal oxygen from the P2W18 cluster. The CuI O bond lengths are in the range of 2.268(17)-2.746(17)Å, and the CuI N bond lengths are in the range of 1.858(19)-1.931(19)Å ( ). The 4,4'-bipyridine groups serve as bidentate ligands and bridge adjacent copper centers. Because of the N-ethylbipyridine cation present, precluding coordination to the transition-metal and resulting in the seven copper atoms form 1D [CuI 7(Bpy)6(BpyEt)2] chains. The connection of alternating the equatorial terminal O atoms of P2W18 clusters and the Cu2 and Cu3 atoms of [CuI 7(Bpy)6(BpyEt)2] chains forms a unique 2D layer ( ), and two adjacent 2D layers are linked by Cu4 atoms of [CuI 7(Bpy)6(BpyEt)2] chains via CuO (the polar terminal O atoms) bonds, resulting in a 3D network ( a). For perspicuous representation, the P2W18 clusters are represented by quadrangle and bpy ligands are represented by sticks (b). The 3D network can be simplified as a ladder like motif (b). The bond-valence calculations  indicate that all the O atoms in 1 are in the -2 oxidation state, and that all W atoms are in the +6 oxidation state and all Cu atoms are in the +1 oxidation state, which has further been confirmed by the absence of signal in the EPR spectrum of compound 1.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>IR spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The IR spectrum of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits characteristic peaks of the Dawson-type polyoxoanions at low-wavenumber region (). The characteristic peak at 1090<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> is assigned to the P<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> stretching vibration. Peak at 954<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> is attributed to the W<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O<ce:inf loc="post">t</ce:inf> stretching vibration and peaks at 909 and 784<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> belong to W<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O<ce:inf loc="post">e</ce:inf>/<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>W stretching modes of the P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>W<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf> cluster. The characteristic bands at 1417, 1490, 1539, and 1611<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> can be regarded as features of the ring-stretching vibrations of the 4,4′-bipyridine ligand, which are of low intensity compared with those of the polyoxoanions. The bands at about 1370 and 1460<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> are assigned to <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>(C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H) and the absorption in the range of 2800–3000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> corresponds to <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H) of the CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>. In addition, a broad feature at about 3440<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> must be assigned to the absorptions of coordinated and lattice water molecules.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
IR spectroscopy

The IR spectrum of compound 1 exhibits characteristic peaks of the Dawson-type polyoxoanions at low-wavenumber region (). The characteristic peak at 1090cm-1 is assigned to the POa stretching vibration. Peak at 954cm-1 is attributed to the WOt stretching vibration and peaks at 909 and 784cm-1 belong to WOe/c W stretching modes of the P2W18 cluster. The characteristic bands at 1417, 1490, 1539, and 1611cm-1 can be regarded as features of the ring-stretching vibrations of the 4,4'-bipyridine ligand, which are of low intensity compared with those of the polyoxoanions. The bands at about 1370 and 1460cm-1 are assigned to δ(CH) and the absorption in the range of 2800-3000cm-1 corresponds to ν(CH) of the CH2 and CH3. In addition, a broad feature at about 3440cm-1 must be assigned to the absorptions of coordinated and lattice water molecules.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In conclusion, a new 3D organic–inorganic hybrid compound constructed by saturated Dawson polyoxoanions and transition-metal coordination complexes (containing <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-ethylated bpy) [Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(BpyEt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] has been isolated under hydrothermal condition. Structure analysis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> provides information for our works: the copper<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> ions and the bpy ligands are good candidates for the construction of 3D transition-metal coordination complexes modified POMs with high connectivity; the <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-ethylbipyridine cation present in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, it has been further demonstrated that the transfer of the alkyl group from the source (methanol or ethanol) takes place in the presence of oxalate and group 6 metal polyoxoanions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, a new 3D organic-inorganic hybrid compound constructed by saturated Dawson polyoxoanions and transition-metal coordination complexes (containing N-ethylated bpy) [CuI 7(Bpy)6(BpyEt)2] has been isolated under hydrothermal condition. Structure analysis of 1 provides information for our works: the copperI ions and the bpy ligands are good candidates for the construction of 3D transition-metal coordination complexes modified POMs with high connectivity; the N-ethylbipyridine cation present in compound 1, it has been further demonstrated that the transfer of the alkyl group from the source (methanol or ethanol) takes place in the presence of oxalate and group 6 metal polyoxoanions.

</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A mixture of K<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>W<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">62</ce:inf>·14H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.088<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), oxalic acid dihydrate (0.02<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (0.062<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in a mixture of ethanol (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was stirred for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min (pH about 2.0). The mixture was then sealed in a 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon reactor and kept under autogenous pressure at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 5 days, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Preparation of compound 1 

A mixture of K6P2W18O62⋅14H2O (0.5g, 0.1mmol), Cu(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.088g, 0.3mmol), oxalic acid dihydrate (0.02g, 0.2mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (0.062g, 0.4mmol) in a mixture of ethanol (2mL) and H2O (8mL) was stirred for 30min (pH about 2.0). The mixture was then sealed in a 23mL Teflon reactor and kept under autogenous pressure at 160°C for 5 days, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10°Ch-1. Red crystals were obtained in 54% yield (based on W). Anal. Calcd (%) for C84H89Cu7K2N16O131P4W36 (10683.78): C, 9.44; H, 0.84; Cu, 4.16; K, 0.73; N, 2.09; P, 1.15; W, 61.95. Found (%): C, 9.86; H, 0.83; Cu, 4.00; K, 0.68; N, 2.00; P, 1.06; W, 61.75.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of a     P   2     W   18     O   62   6 -     polyoxoanion, a K+ ion, a [CuI 3.5(Bpy)3(BpyEt)]9/2+ moieties and 3.5 water molecules ( a). The polyoxoanion     P   2     W   18     O   62   6 -     is a classical Dawson-type structure, which may be described as two [α-PW9O34]3- units, generated from the well-known [α-PW12O40]3- by removal of a set of three corner-sharing WO6 octahedra and fused into a cluster of virtual D 3h symmetry. In the polyoxoanion, the two central P atoms are tetrahedronly coordinated by four bridging oxygen atoms, forming two {PO4} clusters. The corresponding PO bond distances vary from 1.516(13) to 1.568(14). The polyoxoanion contains only two structurally distinct types of W atoms: six polar W atoms on vertical mirror planes grouped in two sets of three and twelve equatorial W atoms that do not lie on mirror planes grouped in two sets of six. According to the different manner of oxygen coordination, four kinds of O atoms exist in the polyoxoanion: 18 terminal O atoms only bonded to one W atom, 36 bridging O atoms shared by two W atoms, 6 bridging O atoms combined with one central P atom and two W atoms, and 2 bridging O atoms coordinated to one central P atom and three W atoms. The corresponding WO bond distances vary from 1.660(14) to 1.733(15), 1.860(13) to 1.978(14), 2.290(11) to 2.466(12), and 2.359(14) to 2.406(13)Å, respectively. All bond lengths are within the normal ranges and consist with those described in the literatures. Further studies reveal that 1 is a 3D architecture, in which each P2W18 cluster acts as tetra-dentate ligand covalently bonding to five copper centers (shown in b). There are four crystallographically independent CuI atoms, which have three different coordination geometries. Cu1 displays a linear {CuN2} coordination geometry, and Cu2 and Cu3 are four-coordinated, defined by two nitrogen atoms from 4,4'-bipyridine and two terminal oxygen from the P2W18 cluster, while Cu4 residing in a T-shaped geometry, is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from 4,4'-bipyridine and a terminal oxygen from the P2W18 cluster. The CuI O bond lengths are in the range of 2.268(17)-2.746(17)Å, and the CuI N bond lengths are in the range of 1.858(19)-1.931(19)Å ( ). The 4,4'-bipyridine groups serve as bidentate ligands and bridge adjacent copper centers. Because of the N-ethylbipyridine cation present, precluding coordination to the transition-metal and resulting in the seven copper atoms form 1D [CuI 7(Bpy)6(BpyEt)2] chains. The connection of alternating the equatorial terminal O atoms of P2W18 clusters and the Cu2 and Cu3 atoms of [CuI 7(Bpy)6(BpyEt)2] chains forms a unique 2D layer ( ), and two adjacent 2D layers are linked by Cu4 atoms of [CuI 7(Bpy)6(BpyEt)2] chains via CuO (the polar terminal O atoms) bonds, resulting in a 3D network ( a). For perspicuous representation, the P2W18 clusters are represented by quadrangle and bpy ligands are represented by sticks (b). The 3D network can be simplified as a ladder like motif (b). The bond-valence calculations  indicate that all the O atoms in 1 are in the -2 oxidation state, and that all W atoms are in the +6 oxidation state and all Cu atoms are in the +1 oxidation state, which has further been confirmed by the absence of signal in the EPR spectrum of compound 1.

IR spectroscopy

The IR spectrum of compound 1 exhibits characteristic peaks of the Dawson-type polyoxoanions at low-wavenumber region (). The characteristic peak at 1090cm-1 is assigned to the POa stretching vibration. Peak at 954cm-1 is attributed to the WOt stretching vibration and peaks at 909 and 784cm-1 belong to WOe/c W stretching modes of the P2W18 cluster. The characteristic bands at 1417, 1490, 1539, and 1611cm-1 can be regarded as features of the ring-stretching vibrations of the 4,4'-bipyridine ligand, which are of low intensity compared with those of the polyoxoanions. The bands at about 1370 and 1460cm-1 are assigned to δ(CH) and the absorption in the range of 2800-3000cm-1 corresponds to ν(CH) of the CH2 and CH3. In addition, a broad feature at about 3440cm-1 must be assigned to the absorptions of coordinated and lattice water molecules.

metadata.title:
A 3D architecture constructed by saturated Dawson polyoxoanions and transition-metal coordination complexes [CuI
               7(Bpy)6(BpyEt)2]
